level_info.name: C Variables & Data Types
level_info.description: Understanding C variables, data types, and memory management

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a valid variable name in C?
questions.explanation: Variable names in C can start with a letter or underscore, but not with a number or contain hyphens. 'int' is a reserved keyword.

questions.question_text: What is the size of an 'int' data type in most modern systems?
questions.explanation: On most modern 32-bit and 64-bit systems, an 'int' is typically 4 bytes (32 bits), though this can vary by system.

questions.question_text: How do you declare a constant in C?
questions.explanation: The 'const' keyword is used to declare constants in C. Once initialized, const variables cannot be modified.

questions.question_text: What is the correct way to declare multiple variables of the same type?
options: int a; int b; int c;
questions.explanation: You can declare multiple variables either on separate lines or on the same line separated by commas. Both methods are valid.

questions.question_text: Which data type is used to store a single character in C?
questions.explanation: The 'char' data type stores a single character and occupies 1 byte of memory. C doesn't have a built-in string data type.

questions.question_text: What happens to uninitialized local variables in C?
questions.explanation: Uninitialized local variables contain garbage values (whatever was previously in that memory location). Always initialize variables before use.

questions.question_text: Which operator is used to get the address of a variable?
questions.explanation: The '&' operator (address-of operator) returns the memory address of a variable. This is fundamental for pointer operations.

questions.question_text: What is the range of values for an unsigned char?
questions.explanation: An unsigned char uses 8 bits (1 byte) and can represent values from 0 to 255. A signed char ranges from -128 to 127.

questions.question_text: Which format specifier is used to print an integer in printf()?
questions.explanation: %d is used for integers, %s for strings, %c for characters, and %f for floating-point numbers.

questions.question_text: What is the difference between '5' and 5 in C?
options: '5' is a character, 5 is an integer
'5' is a string, 5 is a number
questions.explanation: '5' (with quotes) is a character literal with ASCII value 53, while 5 is an integer literal with value 5.
